factoid: Dólokhov turned around.
Dólokhov dropped his hands.
Dólokhov took the bottle.
Dólokhov lifted the bottle to his lips.
Dólokhov threw back his head.
Dólokhov raised his free hand to balance himself.
A footman had stooped to pick up broken glass.
The footman remained in that position.
The footman did not look away from the window.
The footman did not look away from Dólokhov's back.
Anatole stood erect with staring eyes.
The Englishman looked on sideways.
The Englishman pursed up his lips.
A man who had wished to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room.
The man threw himself on a sofa.
The man had his face to the wall.
Pierre hid his face.
Pierre had a faint smile that did not fade.
Pierre's features expressed horror and fear.
All people were still.
Pierre took his hands from his eyes.
Dólokhov sat in the same position.
Dólokhov's head was thrown further back.
Dólokhov's curly hair touched his shirt collar.
Dólokhov's hand holding the bottle was lifted higher and higher.
Dólokhov's hand trembled with effort.
The bottle was emptying perceptibly.
The bottle was rising still higher.
Dólokhov's head was tilting further back.
Pierre thought, "Why is it so long?"
Pierre thought that more than half an hour had elapsed.
Dólokhov made a backward movement with his spine.
Dólokhov's arm trembled nervously.
The backward movement caused Dólokhov’s whole body to slip.
Dólokhov sat on a sloping ledge.
As Dólokhov began slipping down, his head wavered.
As Dólokhov began slipping down, his arm wavered.
Dólokhov's hand moved as if to clutch the window sill.
Dólokhov's hand refrained from touching the window sill.
Pierre covered his eyes again.
Pierre thought he would never open his eyes again.
Pierre became aware of a stir all around.
Pierre looked up.
Dólokhov was standing on the window sill.
Dólokhov had a pale but radiant face.
Dólokhov said, "It’s empty."
Dólokhov threw the bottle to the Englishman.
The Englishman caught the bottle neatly.
Dólokhov jumped down.
Dólokhov smelled strongly of rum.
Voices shouted, "Well done!" "Fine fellow!" "There’s a bet for you!" "Devil take you!"
The Englishman took out his purse.
The Englishman began counting out the money.
Dólokhov stood frowning.
Dólokhov did not speak.
Pierre jumped upon the window sill.
Pierre cried, "Gentlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I’ll do the same thing!"
Pierre shouted, "Even without a bet, there! Tell them to bring me a bottle. I’ll do it." "Bring a bottle!"
Dólokhov said, "Let him do it, let him do it." Dólokhov smiled.
Voices exclaimed, "What next? Have you gone mad?" "No one would let you!" "Why, you go giddy even on a staircase?"
Pierre shouted, "I’ll drink it!" "Let’s have a bottle of rum!" Pierre banged the table with a determined and drunken gesture.
Pierre was preparing to climb out of the window.
They seized Pierre by his arms.
Pierre was so strong that everyone who touched him was sent flying.
Anatole said, "No, you’ll never manage him that way."
Anatole said, "Wait a bit and I’ll get round him." Anatole said, "Listen! I’ll take your bet tomorrow, but now we are all going to ——’s."
Pierre cried, "Come on then." Pierre cried, "Come on!" Pierre said, "And we’ll take Bruin with us."
Pierre caught the bear.
Pierre took the bear in his arms.
Pierre lifted the bear from the ground.
Pierre began dancing around the room with the bear.
Prince Vasíli kept the promise he had given to Princess Drubetskáya.
Princess Drubetskáya had spoken to Prince Vasíli on behalf of her only son Borís.
Princess Drubetskáya spoke to Prince Vasíli on the evening of Anna Pávlovna’s soiree.
The matter was mentioned to the Emperor.
An exception was made.
Borís was transferred into the regiment of Semënov Guards.
Borís had the rank of cornet.
Prince Vasíli did not receive an appointment to Kutúzov’s staff.
Anna Mikháylovna made endeavors and entreaties.
Anna Mikháylovna returned to Moscow after Anna Pávlovna’s reception.
Anna Mikháylovna went straight to her rich relations, the Rostóvs.
Anna Mikháylovna stayed with the Rostóvs when in the town.
Bóry had only just entered a regiment of the line.
Bóry was being transferred to the Guards as a cornet.
Bóry had been educated from childhood.
The Guards had left Petersburg on the tenth of August.
Anna Mikháylovna's son remained in Moscow for his equipment.
Anna Mikháylovna's son was to join the Guards on the march to Radzivílov.
